shortTermOutlook.stateDescription: The bullish and bearish events are balanced.

longTermOutlook.stateDescription: Recent bullish events outweigh bearish events.

msBullishSummary: Devon's acreage is ideally located in the core portions of the basins in which it operates. That translates to above-average well performance and peer-leading supply costs.
Devon’s shareholder-friendly capital allocation plan opens the door for substantial returns to shareholders via a base dividend, variable dividend, and opportunistic buybacks.
By capping growth at 5% annually, Devon avoids the risk of overspending during upcycles, a common fault of upstream firms.
msBearishSummary: After incorporating costs sunk on leasehold, acquisitions, exploration, and infrastructure, Devon's capital base inflates to a level that puts excess returns on capital out of reach.
The profitability of Devon’s Permian assets is unmatched elsewhere in the portfolio.
Production growth could periodically outpace midstream capacity additions in the Permian Basin, causing bottlenecks and volatile basis differentials.

researchReports.title: Raising fixed dividend by 5% to $0.22 per share
researchReports.summary: Based in Oklahoma City, Devon has operations in New Mexico (Delaware Basin), North Dakota (Williston Basin), Oklahoma (Anadarko Basin), Texas (Eagle Ford) and Wyoming (Powder River Basin). On January 7, 2021, Devon completed a 'merger of equals' with WPX Energy. The combination created a leading shale oil producer in the U.S. The company has approximately 1600 employees.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: DVN, THO, SPLK
reports.reportTitle: U.S. markets pulled back on Thursday on hotter-than-expected inflation data. In February, headline PPI rose 0.6%, up from 0.2% in January and ahead of the expected 0.3% increase -- with nearly two-thirds of the increase attributed to a rise in prices for final-demand goods. The U.S. Census Bureau reported that sales in January were down 1.3%. Leading the decline were merchant wholesalers (-1.7%), while retailer sales slipped 1.1%, and manufacturer sales declined 1.0%. Inventories were essentially flat, as a 0.4% rise in retail inventories was offset by a 0.3% drop in merchant wholesaler and 0.1% decline in manufacturer inventories. Initial jobless claims for the week were 209,000, down 1,000 from the previous-week's revised level. The Dow fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 was down 0.3%, and the Nasdaq lost 0.3%. Crude oil traded above $81 per barrel, while gold fell $13 to $2167 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: We have an Under-Weight rating on the Energy Sector. Companies in the sector saw their earnings crushed in the last quarter and things looks bad for this quarter as well. Still, there are individual names we like and there is a trend of consolidation in the sector, all of which has piqued our interest. Exxon Mobil is buying Pioneer Natural and Chevron is buying Hess. We think this might prompt other big oil companies to look around as well. We think Conoco Phillips could be in the market to scoop up a smaller company (possibly Devon, EOG, or Marathon Oil). We don't think there will be any regulatory hurdles, as consolidation could lead oil prices to retreat, which would help the overall U.S. economy as inflation is still high in many areas. So it would seem to be in the government's interest to allow these deals to go through. Energy accounts for only about 3%-4% of total S&P 500 capitalization, but the sector often acts as a hedge to the broader market -- so having exposure to the group is important. Energy tends to zigs when the S&P 500 zags.  Indeed, in 2022, the S&P 500 declined 19.4% while the Energy sector advanced 59%.  In the August-October period of 2023, the S&P 500 fell more than 8% while the Energy sector declined only 3%. The following is a list of names we like overall in both Oil and Energy.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bearish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: In past commentaries, we have talked about a potential U.S. Dollar Index (USD) rally, detailing its bearish implications for precious metals (GLD, SLV) and crypto (specifically Bitcoin and Ethereum). On Wednesday, the greenback continued its ascent, reaching its highest level since March 17. USD has bullishly pushed back above its 10- and 21-week exponential averages after losing them last November. At its recent low seven weeks ago, the greenback was slightly under its low from February 1, setting up both a bullish daily momentum divergence and a minor false breakdown.

That compared to this. 'Forecasted probability of recession at levels only seen during recessions.' Yes, these are confusing times.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: ABC, DVN, HD, NVDA, PANW
reports.reportTitle: Stocks gave up early gains on Thursday morning, extending their recent losses. GDP data pointed to slower growth and higher inflation. The Commerce Department said that the U.S. economy expanded at a 2.7% annualized rate in 4Q, down from its prior forecast of 2.9%. It also reported a 3.7% increase in the personal consumption expenditures price index, up from an initial estimate of 3.2%. On the employment front, first-time claims for state unemployment benefits fell by 3,000 to a seasonally adjusted 192,000 for the week ended February 18, below the Reuters consensus forecast of 200,000. The Dow fell 0.5%, the S&P 0.3%, and the Nasdaq 0.4%. Crude oil rose more than 1% to $75 per barrel, while gold fell $13 to $1829 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: On Wednesday, the Federal Reserve hiked the fed funds rate by 50 basis points (bps) to a target range of 4.25% to 4.5%, which was expected. However, Fed Chairman Jerome Powell remains steadfast in his intent to keep the brake pedal on the floor and doesn't see the Fed cutting rates until they are confident inflation is moving down to 2%. Expectations for the funds rate rose to 5.1% (by the end of next year).

reports.headHtml: The Argus ESG Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Sustainable Impact Investing, or ESG investing, is gaining traction not only with Argus Research clients but also with the global investment community. BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $9 trillion in assets, announced in January 2020 that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. He doubled down in his January 2021 letter, calling on company managements to disclose their plans for making their businesses "compatible with a net-zero economy" by 2050. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol, and firearms. Performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter, and workers' rights.

reports.headHtml: The Argus Innovation Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Innovation may be hard to define. But to borrow from former U.S. Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart, you know it when you see it. The United States economy is full of innovation. It has to be. Manufacturing industries that dominated the economy decades ago - textiles, televisions, even automobiles to a large degree - have moved overseas, where labor and materials costs are lower. Yet the U.S. economy, even during the pandemic and the current period of high inflation, has expanded to record levels. If U.S. corporations weren't innovating, creating new products (such as vaccines) and services (such as Zoom calls) and moving into new markets and applications, the domestic economy would not be growing, and capital would not be flooding into the country. The current high level of the U.S. dollar relative to currencies around the world attests to the confidence that global investors have in the innovative U.S. economy.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: When the major indices are all higher by around 1% percent on a given day, it should be a good day. (Especially after what investors have endured so far in 2022.) But sometimes, statistics can be deceiving. Markets that truly are coming out of a major corrections or bear markets respond with consistent strength from a price perspective and also achieve very strong market breadth statistics. Unfortunately, yesterday just wasn't one of those days.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: In this market, one must take on a herd mentality. When the narrative changes, investors do a 180. After weakness since mid-August and into the end of September and with the S&P 500 down 17% in six weeks, the month and quarter turned over and investors' appetite for stocks turned on a dime. Over the past two days, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq surged 5.7%, with the QQQs popping 5.6%. The IWM soared 6.8% and the S&P 400 rocketed 7%. There has been broad participation and clear evidence of risk-on behavior over the past two days -- with Energy swelling 10%, and Materials, Industrials, Technology, Financials, and Communication Services all rising 6% to 7%.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Despite a late-day rally attempt, the stock market was weak again on Tuesday. That makes three straight days of losses and six declines over the past eight days. Interestingly, the S&P 500, Nasdaq, and Nasdaq 100 all broke their 50-day moving averages for the first time since April. It was also noteworthy that the three indices also fell below their respective 50% retracements of the rally off the June lows -- but finished very close to this potential support level.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Devon Energy Corp.
reports.reportTitle: Based in Oklahoma City, Devon employs approximately 1,600 people across onshore oil, natural gas liquids, and natural gas assets located in New Mexico (Delaware Basin), North Dakota (Williston Basin), Oklahoma (Anadarko Basin), Texas (Eagle Ford) and Wyoming (Powder River Basin). On January 7, 2021, Devon completed a 'merger of equals' transaction with WPX Energy. The strategic combination created a leading unconventional (shale) oil producer in the U.S.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rallied on Wednesday when the Fed (as expected) hiked interest rates by 75 basis points and Fed Chair Powell reiterated a commitment to stop inflation regardless of the risks to the economy.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bearish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Crude oil has been one of the more-volatile markets since the middle of June. WTI peaked at $123.68 on June 14, and traced out an ABC decline to $95.10 as of July 6. It rebounded Thursday, finishing at $102.26, up 3.8%. As we have said, key chart support as well as the 200-day average sits in the low $90s. On the upside, there is significant chart resistance overhead starting in the $110 region.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Stocks got pasted again on Monday, with the S&P 500 down almost 4% and the Nasdaq and QQQs off 4.6%. Over the past three trading sessions, the "500" has plunged 9% and the Nasdaq and the QQQs have plummeted about 10.5%. This is the largest three-day collapse for the "500" and the Nasdaq since the pandemic began, and the largest decline for the QQQs since September 2020.

reports.headHtml: The Argus ESG Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Sustainable Impact Investing, or ESG investing, is gaining traction not only with Argus Research clients but also with the global investment community. BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $9 trillion in assets, announced in January 2020 that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. He doubled down in his January 2021 letter, calling on company managements to disclose their plans for making their businesses "compatible with a net-zero economy" by 2050. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol, and firearms. Performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter, and workers' rights.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bearish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Yet another brutal day for stocks on Wednesday, with some of the major indices making minor corrective closing lows. The S&P 500 got clipped for 4% and is now down almost 18% in 2022. It was the largest one-day decline for the "500" since June 2020. The Nasdaq plummeted 4.7% while the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) plunged 4.9%. NYSE breadth was -2,512, almost equaling the worst breadth day of -2,626 (from May 9) since the correction started. It was an 88% day when looking at declining volume/total volume and declining issues/total issues on the NYSE. Crude oil also took a big hit, with WTI falling 5% and Brent crude losing 2.6%.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Devon Energy Corp.
reports.reportTitle: Devon Energy is a leading independent energy company engaged in oil and gas exploration, production and property acquisitions. Based in Oklahoma City, Devon is among the largest U.S.-based independent oil and gas producers (E&P) and is included in the S&P 500 index. The company's operations are focused onshore in the United States and Canada.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: ADTN, DVN, EBAY, HST, OC, FTV
reports.reportTitle: Stocks finished mostly lower on Thursday after paring sharp early losses. Investors weighed more hot inflation data, though producer prices did show slightly slower year-over-year growth in April than in March. The Labor Department reported that its PPI for final demand rose 11% from the prior year in April, down from 11.5% in March but above consensus. On the employment front, first-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 203,000 for the week ended May 7, up from a revised 202,000 a week earlier and above the consensus estimate. The Dow fell 0.33%, the S&P fell 0.13%, and the Nasdaq rose 0.06%. Crude oil traded near $107 per barrel, while gold fell $32 to $1822 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bearish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Thursday was yet another brutal day for stocks, especially after Wednesday's strong gains. Risk On. Risk Off. It never seems to end! The S&P 500 is back near its closing lows after cratering 3.6%, its worst day since April 29. NYSE breadth was horrible at -2,725. NYSE declining volume/total volume and declining issues/total issues both registered 90% days, a pretty good washout, at least for a day.

reports.headHtml: The Argus Innovation Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Innovation may be hard to define. But to borrow from former U.S. Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart, you know it when you see it. The United States economy is full of innovation. It has to be. Manufacturing industries that dominated the economy decades ago - textiles, televisions, even automobiles to a large degree - have moved overseas, where costs are lower. Yet the U.S. economy, even during the pandemic, has expanded to record levels. If U.S. corporations weren't innovating, creating new products (such as vaccines) and services and moving into new markets and applications, the domestic economy would not be growing, and capital would not be flooding into the country. Consider that U.S. GDP was approximately $1 trillion in 1930 but was more than $24 trillion at the end of 2021. That's growth of 24-times. Meanwhile, the U.S. population has grown less than three-times during that time span, to 320 million from 120 million. The delta between GDP growth and population growth has been driven, in large part, by innovation.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The entire yield curve has fallen a bit over the past couple of days. While the broader uptrend for yields remains unbroken, it is a nice relief for the stock market, and especially the higher-beta names and indices that were in danger of testing their bear-market lows. The S&P 500 rose 1.1% on Wednesday, while the Nasdaq and the QQQs jumped 2%. NYSE breadth was good at +1,964 while we saw an 80% day with respect to advancing issues/total issues and advancing volume/total volume. The 2/10 spread, after sneaking into negative territory ever so slightly, is back to +33 basis points. So it seems the recession is off for now (!!).

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Neutral in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Several developments are needed in order to confirm a market bottom after an intermediate-term correction, a mini bear market, or a longer-term bear market. In the simplest form, when price continues to make lower closes (not day after day) following counter-trend rallies, we like to see bullish divergences in momentum and breadth. This shows that price is weaker, but momentum and breadth are actually improving. Following these positive divergences, we then must get momentum and breadth to go from weak (oversold) to strong (overbought) to get confirmation of a bottom.

reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: We recently raised our rating on the Energy sector to Over-Weight from Market-Weight. Already strong demand for petroleum products (related to global reopening) is now exacerbated by the war in Ukraine, which has led to broad sanctions on Russia and may exclude this major supplier from the global energy markets. Although we expect other counties to add to supply, we expect energy prices to remain elevated at least through year-end. Energy accounts for 3.6% of S&P 500 market cap; over the past five years, the weighting has ranged from 2% to 10%. We think investors should consider allocating 4%-5% of diversified portfolios to the group. The sector is outperforming thus far in 2022, with a gain of 32.3%. It also outperformed in 2021, with a gain of 47.7%. It underperformed in 2020, with a loss of 37.3%, and in 2019, with a gain of 7.6%.  Here are some of the Energy sector companies that are on our BUY List. Some also are featured in our model portfolios (Growth & Income, Equity Income, Growth, and Institutional) and in our Focus List.

Crude surged over 9% on Tuesday, closing near $105 and hitting an intraday high of almost $107 after Monday's 4.5% jump. Gasoline futures closed over $3/gallon, with much of the oil complex at their highest levels since 2014. Do you think the federal government has ever thought of a flexible gasoline tax to smooth things out for consumers?

The National Association of Realtors said that U.S. existing home sales rose 6.7% in January to an annualized 6.5 million, well above the Bloomberg consensus forecast of 6.1 million. reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: Oil prices are near $85 per barrel of West Texas Intermediate crude and continue a climb that began in April 2020, when the price was below $20. We think these relatively high prices will support the Energy sector, which has outperformed the market this year, in the near term. Within the group, we favor companies with a high exposure to U.S. production, as well as those with clean balance sheets and a history of growing dividends. Here are the Energy companies that are on our Focus List or that are used in our model portfolios.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bearish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The S&P 500 tested its 200-day average on Friday, but failed as more late-day selling hit the tape. This follows the breaking of a cluster of support near 4,570. This is the first 200-day test/break from above since February 2020, back when the pandemic was just getting started.

reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: Investors wrapped up a quiet final week in 2021 with a modest loss for the S&P 500.  But that hardly dented a strong year for stocks, when the S&P 500 climbed almost 27%. The average stock in the Argus Universe of Coverage rose 24% during the quarter, and the median stock advanced 36%. The average BUY-rated stock increased 28%, while the average HOLD-rated stock gained 15%. Will investors continue to favor value in 2021? Will small-caps reverse their recent weak trend?  Given low interest rates, we expect growth stocks to resume outperformance over time. Investors seeking value are encouraged to focus on dividends and look for yields in the 3%-4% range. As for small-caps, the promise of the vaccine is encouraging for these companies, which typically don't have the gilt-edged balance sheets of large-caps and are thus more dependent on a strong U.S. economy. Small-cap valuations remain depressed, and this group looks to offer value into 2022.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The final trading day of 2021 is here, and the S&P 500 is positioned for its best gain since...two years ago, in 2019. Still, 20%-plus gainer years on the S&P 500 are not all that common. Since the millennial turn in 2000, the index has posted a gain of at least 20% just four other times: in 2003, 2009, 2013, and 2019.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The S&P 500 sprinted to all-time highs on Monday. The nice breakout over the 4,745 region measures up to the 4,950 zone for the index. There are other targets based on the prior cup-with-handle between 4,813 and the 4,980 area. In good news, the 5-day/13-day exponential moving average (EMA) crossover and the 8/13 EMA crossover are both back to bullish. In addition, the 14-day RSI has broken its downtrend off the early November peak. On the downside, the rising 50-day EMA is at 4,620, and the recent price lows between 4,495 and 4,531 are initial chart support.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: As of Wednesday's close, the S&P 500 was 4.1% below its closing high from November 18. Considering the volatility, things could be worse. The Nasdaq has dipped 5% from its closing high on 11/19, while the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) has dropped 4.2% over the past seven days. The smaller stocks have felt the real pain -- and those declines started back on November 9. The Russell 2000 (IWM) has cascaded 12.1% on a closing basis in 16 days, while the S&P MidCap 400 has given up 8.5% over the past 10 days. Breakouts for both indices to all-time highs in late October/early November have failed miserably.

reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: ESG (Environmental, Social, Governance) investing continues to grow.  According to Opimas, a management consultancy focused on global capital markets, global assets under management in ESG strategies had grown to $40.5 trillion in 2020, doubling in four years and tripling in eight years. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol and firearms. In time, the list of industries to avoid increased to include soft drinks, fast food, and oil and gas, among numerous others. Performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as the climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter, and workers' rights. For our part, we track ESG developments at specific companies as part of our Management analysis - one of the six points in our proprietary Six-Point Fundamental Approach. In addition to following the ESG proclamations from the companies under coverage, we partner with an ESG research firm, the JUST Capital Foundation, and leverage its analysis and insights as well. JUST Capital's mission is to drive measurable corporate change to create a stakeholder-centric, inclusive form of capitalism that reflects the priorities of the American public. JUST utilizes a combination of data-driven research and strategic engagement in an attempt to shift norms and practices in corporate America and the financial markets. Environment, and Shareholders. JUST ESG Custom Ratings rank stocks in the Russell 1000 on these criteria using a scale of 1-100. Drawing on the JUST Capital rankings, we have compiled focused lists of companies followed by Argus Research that are in position to have this type of "sustainable impact" on the environment, workplace, community, and marketplace. These firms have exemplary records not only in delivering on the bottom line, but also in improving the environment, contributing to community relations, and showing respect for their employees. We have lists focused on the top companies in each sector, as well as lists of companies that score well on certain financial metrics, such as yield, beta, value, and momentum. We also have a Theme Model Portfolio based in part on the ESG criteria. To build the Argus U.S. ESG Model Portfolio, we applied financial concepts such as industry diversification, income generation, risk reduction and growth at a reasonable price to our various lists. In addition, all stocks must be on the Argus BUY list. Here are the new stocks that have been added to the Argus U.S. ESG Model Portfolio.

reports.headHtml: The Argus ESG Model Portfolio
reports.reportTitle: Sustainable Impact Investing is gaining traction with the global investment community. In January 2020, BlackRock CEO Lawrence Fink, who oversees approximately $9 trillion in assets, announced that his firm would be investing in companies that are making progress on sustainability. He doubled down in his January 2021 letter, calling on company managements to disclose their plans for making their businesses "compatible with a net-zero economy" by 2050. As assets have flowed in over the past 40 years, Sustainable Impact Investing has evolved. The discipline, originally known as Socially Responsible Investing, focused at first on excluding companies that conducted business in South Africa, or participated in industries such as tobacco, alcohol, and firearms. But the performance of these initial strategies lagged, and the approach has been modified. Now, instead of merely identifying industries to avoid, the discipline promotes "sustainable" business practices across all industries that can have an "impact" on global issues such as the climate, hunger, poverty, disease, shelter, and workers' rights.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Devon Energy Corp.
reports.reportTitle: Devon Energy is a leading independent energy company engaged in oil and gas exploration, production and property acquisitions. Based in Oklahoma City, Devon is among the largest U.S.-based independent oil and gas producers and is included in the S&P 500 index. The company's operations are focused onshore in the United States and Canada.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: CAKE, DVN, EPD, HLF, HFC, LHX, MGM, SWKS, VMC, CBOE, APO
reports.reportTitle: As major stock indices trade near all-time highs and the VIX volatility index rests near its lowest level since the start of the pandemic, the volume of insider transactions has risen to the highest level since early September. The snap-back in volume is not surprising given pent-up demand from the recent earnings hiatus. Furthermore, after a year of impressive returns for the stock market, executives, directors, and beneficial owners may be engaging in year-end tax planning as capital-gains issues loom large these days.

reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: Due to a difficult September, in which the S&P 500 fell 4.7%, 3Q21 was barely positive for stocks, with the major benchmark index increasing only 0.6%.  The average stock in the Argus Universe of Coverage fell 1.7% during the quarter, and the median stock dropped 1.4%. The average BUY-rated stock slipped 0.9%, while the average HOLD-rated stock declined 3.7%. Will investors continue to favor value in 2021?  Will small-caps reverse their recent weak trend? Given low interest rates, we expect growth stocks to resume their outperformance over time, and think this may be the one-in-five years that value leads. Investors seeking value are encouraged to focus on dividends and look for yields in the 3%-4% range. As for small-caps, the promise of the vaccine is encouraging for these companies, which typically don't have the gilt-edged balance sheets of large-caps and are thus more dependent on a strong U.S. economy. Small-cap valuations remain depressed, and this group looks to offer value into 2022.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: The S&P 500 broke its streak of seven straight monthly gains in September, losing 4.8%. The Nasdaq Composite fell 5.3%, the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) gave up 5.7%, the Dow Industrials declined 4.3%, the S&P MidCap 400 (MDY) dropped 4%, and the Russell 2000 (IWM) fared the best, dipping only 2.9%.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Although we've said this before, it might be time to keep an eye on interest rates. The 10-year Treasury yield broke lower in early July, and fell to 1.13% on August 4, hitting the low of 1.13% from July 20. The recent yield lows represented a 50% retracement of the move from August until March. Yields stopped right at the 50-week moving average, a bearish sign. After the 8/4 bottom, yields popped right to support from the declining 50-day average at 1.38%. Yields then pulled back to 1.22% and reversed higher back to the 1.34% region, or right where the 50-day is again.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Market breadth for indices and sectors remains mixed. The percentage of stocks in the S&P 500 above their 50-day average has improved to 68% from 37% in mid-July. It would certainly be positive if this percentage continues to improve. The percentage above their 200-day average has risen to 87% from a recent 83%. That is a very strong reading.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Devon Energy Corp.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: ACC, BP, DVN, MNST, HFC, NOK, GM, LEA, MDLZ
reports.reportTitle: Stocks were largely flat on Monday morning as investors weighed positive employment data along with the impact of rising Delta variant cases. The Labor Department's JOLTS report said that U.S. job openings rose by 590,000 to 10.1 million on the last day of June, above the consensus forecast of 9.28 million. Hiring also rose to 6.7 million in June from 6.0 million in May. The data came after a strong July employment report on Friday morning. The Dow fell 0.2%, the S&P fell 0.1%, and the Nasdaq rose 0.1%. Crude oil fell more than 3% to $66 per barrel, while gold dropped $28 to $1735 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: During June, the S&P 500 tacked on 2.2%, while Technology stocks propelled the Nasdaq to a 5.5% gain and the Nasdaq 100 (QQQ) 6.3% higher. The S&P 400 fell 1.1% while the Russell 2000 (IWM) rose 1.9%. The NYSE and the Dow Industrials were flat in June while the Dow Transports lost 5.5%. Once again, the dispersion of returns among the 11 S&P sectors, as well as individual names, was very wide.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Precious metals continue to show signs of life, coming off their March 30 lows as the U.S. Dollar Index (USD) remains in an eight-week downtrend. The USD has given up all its gains off recent lows and is testing key chart support from the lows in January (near $89). Treasury yields have been flat, also helping the metals.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: DVN, M, RCL, KKR, BABA
reports.reportTitle: Stocks continued their recovery on Friday morning, despite weaker-than-expected April retail sales data. The Commerce Department reported that U.S. retail sales were unchanged last month following a 10.7% jump in March. The reading was below the consensus call for 1.0% growth. The Dow rose 0.8%, the S&P 1.1%, and the Nasdaq 1.6%. Crude oil traded near $65 per barrel, while gold rose $16 to $1840 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: Coming off March 30 lows, precious metals continue to show signs of life as the U.S. Dollar Index (USD) remains in a six-week downtrend. The USD has given up all its gains off recent lows and is testing key chart support from the lows in January and February, near $90. Treasury yields continue to trade sideways.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: BYD, DVN, OC, MDLZ, TWLO
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Thursday morning following mixed earnings from Walmart and disappointing employment data. The Labor Department said that first-time claims for state unemployment benefits rose to 861,000 for the week ended February 13, up from a revised 848,000 a week earlier and well above the Bloomberg consensus forecast of 773,000. Continuing claims of 4.494 million were down from the prior week but above the consensus forecast of 4.425 million. The Dow fell 0.6%, the S&P 0.7%, and the Nasdaq 1.1%. Crude oil fell slightly to $61 per barrel, while gold traded near $1776 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: DVN, GSK, NFG, WTRG, LULU, AVGO
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell last week, with a final drop on Friday as hopes for a stimulus plan fizzled. The details, rather than the size of the deal, are the sticking points. A troubling initial UE claims report also weighed on sentiment. On Friday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average eked out a win of 47 points, or 0.16%, as DIS shares rallied. The S&P 500 fell 4 points, or 0.13%, and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 28 points or 0.23%. Last week, the Dow was down 0.6%, the S&P 500 was down 1.0%, and the Nasdaq was down 0.7%. For the year-to-date, the DJIA is up 5.3%. The S&P is up 13.4%, and the Nasdaq remains in front with a gain of 38.0%. Over the past 52 weeks, the Dow is up 6.8%, the S&P 500 is up 15.6%, and the Nasdaq is up 41.7%.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: MMP, ALL, ATVI, AVB, DVN, SKX, VRTX, PSX, CPRI
reports.reportTitle: Stocks snapped back during election week, as the vote count dragged into the weekend. The Republicans likely hold onto the Senate, which means no big tax hikes; and Vice President Biden claims the White House, which means the Affordable Care Act stays. Based on the strong stock market, investors cheered for gridlock. On Friday, the Dow Jones Industrial Average fell 67 points, or 0.2%. The S&P 500 dropped a single point, and the Nasdaq Composite edged up four points. For the full week, the Dow was up 6.9%, reversing the prior week's 6.5% loss. The S&P 500 was up 7.3%, and the Nasdaq was up 9.4%. For the year-to-date, the DJIA is down less than 1%, the S&P is up 8.6%, and the Nasdaq is up 38.5%. Over the past 52 weeks, the Dow is up 2.3%, the S&P 500 is up 13.5%, and the Nasdaq is up 40.4%.

reports.headHtml: Analyst Report: Devon Energy Corp.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: DVN, KMX, PFE
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Tuesday morning, giving back some of Monday's gains as investors awaited the first presidential debate. On the economic front, the Commerce Department said that the U.S. trade deficit in goods rose 3.5% to $82.9 billion in August, reflecting strong imports of consumer goods and slower growth in exports. The increased deficit could weigh on 3Q GDP. Meanwhile, the Conference Board reported that its consumer confidence index rose to 101.8 in September, up from 86.3 in August and well above the Reuters consensus forecast of 89.5. The Dow fell 0.5%, the S&P 0.4%, and the Nasdaq 0.1%. Crude oil traded near $39 per barrel, while gold rose $10 to $1892 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Market Digest: SNY, ACM, DVN, NEE, IPG, J, PXD, LYB
reports.reportTitle: The S&P 500 closed on August 7 in the 3,350s, within 1% of its all-time closing high of 3,386.15. That high was set on 2/19/20, when COVID-19 was still largely a vague concern and not the overwhelming global catastrophe it is now. The market has continued rallying in August, rising by 2.6% in the month-to-date in what is normally a poor month for the S&P 500.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: WYNN, DVN, DD, MDC, WMB, PEG
reports.reportTitle: Stocks rallied on Monday morning following positive data on a potential coronavirus vaccine from Modena and comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell. In an interview on '60 Minutes,' Mr. Powell said he expected the U.S. economy to 'recover steadily' through the second half of the year assuming no second wave of the virus. However, he cautioned that the recovery could stretch through the end of 2021 and that a full recovery would likely require the development of a vaccine. The Dow rose 3.5%, the S&P 3.1%, and the Nasdaq 2.4%. Crude oil rose 12% to $33 per barrel, while gold fell $19 to $1740 per ounce.

reports.reportTitle: Stocks rallied on Monday morning following positive data on a potential coronavirus vaccine from Modena and comments from Fed Chair Jerome Powell. reports.headHtml: Weekly Stock List
reports.reportTitle: Last week was the worst for stocks since the financial crisis. For the week, the S&P 500 plunged 384 points, or 11.5%. The Dow Jones Industrial Average dropped 3,583 points, or 12.4%. The S&P 500 started this week 12% from its all-time high. Is a bear market beginning?  We don't think so, or at least don't think that stocks will be down too long, as positive fundamentals remain intact. The economy is growing at about a 2% pace; interest rates are at historical lows and the Federal Reserve is ready to act; and corporate earnings are on the upswing, after a down year.  Of course, if health officials are unable to contain the coronavirus, then a recession may be coming and a bear market as well. We are somewhat reassured that global health officials have managed previous viral scares such as AIDS, SARS, MERS and Ebola, and stocks have recovered lost ground in a year.  So a little bargain hunting may be in order.  Here are the 10 BUY-rated stocks under Argus Coverage that dropped the most last week.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: NEM, PGR, DVN, ILMN
reports.reportTitle: Stocks fell on Friday morning amid continued coronavirus concerns, including a spike in new cases in South Korea, and weak purchasing managers' data. IHS Markit said that its composite purchasing managers' index fell 3.7 points to 49.6 in February, the lowest level since October 2013. On the earnings front, Deere shares rose more than 8% after the farm equipment maker posted strong fiscal first-quarter earnings and reaffirmed its full-year guidance. The S&P fell 0.8%, the Dow 0.6%, and the Nasdaq 1.2%. Crude oil fell more than 1% to $53 per barrel, while gold jumped $22 to $1642 per ounce.

reports.headHtml: Technical Assessment: Bullish in the Intermediate-Term
reports.reportTitle: There's a characteristic of markets that we have noted many times over the decades: markets are mean reverting. The hot get trashed and the trashed get hot. At one point this year, Real Estate (XLRE) and Utilities (XLU) led the pack. At the other end, Energy (XLE) had been at the bottom all year. Well, the winds are starting to turn.

reports.headHtml: Market Update: LIN, SNY, SWKS, DVN, MYL
reports.reportTitle: Stocks plunged on Wednesday morning, more than reversing Tuesday's gains, on fears that an inverted yield curve raised the risk of a recession. Investors also weighed weak economic data in Germany, where overall output fell 0.1% in the second quarter, and in China, where industrial output in July rose at its slowest pace in more than 17 years. The Dow fell 2.5%, the S&P 2.5%, and the Nasdaq 2.9%. Crude oil fell sharply to about $54.50 per barrel, while gold rose $15 to $1529 per ounce.
